> but strike decks are so so bad
In base game characters, yes. In Hermit, also yes. I don't think Champ strike decks are bad; they're just less optimal than vigor spam right now.
Many of Champ's strike cards do a lot on their own, unlike most of Ironclad's strikes. So combining them into a deck for Champ is much more feasible.

being less optimal then the main champ damage engine makes them bad though. Strike decks have felt awful to me ever since the perfecter strike nerf; you do half as much damage as you did before and even pre nerf it wasn't that overwhelming
champ has so many attacks that work on their own, when thats right next to an archetype that whats you to clog your deck with mediocre ones it doesn't tend to work out.

> being less optimal then the main champ damage engine makes them bad though.
No, that makes the main Champ damage engine overcentralizing. It's the same with Watcher and Rushdown Wrath. That doesn't make the scry and retain strategies bad; it just makes them much less optimal comparatively.

Champ's strikes are really good, especially compared to most of Ironclad's strikes (and DEFINITELY compared to everyone else's strikes). I don't understand how you see them as mediocre unless you're specifically only viewing them in relation to the usual Champ strategy—a strategy that has been often stated as being boringly overpowered and in need of as many nerfs as what the Gremlins need.
I do see them as mediocre because i'm comparing them to the other champ cards
I would do the same for a card like <claw> it can "work" but not reliably at all (and if it does its not going to be as great as orbs or other defect attacks)

embeds.title: Claw
embeds.description:
Common Attack / 0 :blue_energy: / The Defect / Slay the Spire

Deal 3 (5) damage.
Increase the damage of ALL Claw cards by 2 this combat.

messages.content: I feel that Claw is overall weaker than most of Champ's strikes. But also, Defect does have the complaint that Frost Orb spam is the only real consistent way to play the character, so it's more or less the same situation.

Unlike Champ's strike decks, Defect's Claw decks requires you to find multiples of a single card or a LOT of deck manipulation so you can play it repeatedly. You don't need any specific Strike card to start making a Strike deck. Strikes just naturally end up in your deck because of how generally useful Champ's strike cards can be. All you need is to find a few early Strike cards and be like "I guess I'm making a Strike deck now", as opposed to how much you have to go out of your way to make a Defect Claw deck.
And Strike of Genius lets you play those strikes for free and without "clogging" your deck, as you put it.
I think Champ has the second best Strike deck out of characters that I've played—and that's only because The Cursed has numbers and synergies that are just bonkers enough to overtake that.
today I actually managed to make establishment and nirvana work with a rushdown deck
so yeah

There is a massive difference between "This is a bad deck archetype" and "This deck archetype is weaker than this other one". 
Watcher's Pressure Points is a bad archetype; there is only one card and very little support for it; it gets massively shut down by Artifact and anything that may discourage the use of skill spam.
Champ's Strike decks are weaker than spamming Vigor, but they are not themselves bad. They're quite good, in fact. Most people just don't want to use them if they want to guarantee a win.

Again, it's the Watcher Rushdown situation.
admittedly, cursed's curse synergies are so unhinged that their strike deck also goes overshadowed

Strike of genius is a powerful tool to let champ deal consistent damage throughout a fight, potentially getting to focus more of their energy on defense while strike of genius provides most of your offense. It's very strong strike dummy and all the ninja/attack relics, and can scale you even further with kunai and shuriken. It can be a little random in terms of the quality of the resulting strike, especially since the expensive ones are so much better thanks to the cost reduction, and triple strike in particular is very powerful with the ninja relics.

Early on in the run, you usually don't need a source of persistent damage like this on champ, since your vigor stacking and generally high numbers should be enough to end most fights quickly. In the late game, the effect is extremely valuable, largely because champ tends to struggle with chewing through the larger health pools of late game bosses. You also don't have very many good options for scaling on champ, so each of them becomes that much more important to take when you find them, as you can often cruise through acts 1 and 2, only to find yourself without a solution to late act  3 and 4. It is necessary and worth taking even slightly slow or awkward scaling cards early in the run to cover this weakness for champ in my experience. Usually you are so good at frontloading in the early game that taking some late game focused cards in the early game doesn't hurt you that much.

It definitely gets better if you are leaning into strike synergies, but I don't really think you need to even dabble into them to take strike of genius. Unless your deck is hyper focused on stacking vigor and unloading it into a single multihit card, this is just going to be a solid source of scaling damage regardless of how many "strikes "you have. Much easier to play once you have the 4th energy, and I really like the upgrade, it's very impactful, at least +3 damage a turn, which compares favorably to inflame.
Well it's impossible to view them in any way but compared to what the character has.
The only fair comparison you could make for champ's strike deck is champ's other archetypes
and in that comparison strike runs are a lot harder, and a lot more exclusive. Taking vigor spam in a strike deck is a lot more detrimental than taking a strike or two in vigor spam.
That says much more about Vigor than it does about the quality of the Strikes, in my opinion.
Yes but it is a direct comparison on a character. Strikes are bad because there are better options.
It holds little weight to say "this is better than other characters' similar package" because this isn't on said other character.

*Reading this discussion while having plans to nerf **Vigor** decks*:
 Interesting...
Well they should be nerfed
Would be interesting to see how champ worked with other archetypes, since every champ run feels same-y
I want vigor decks to be killed in cold blood

That is the plan, I want to introduce debuff, and Discard synergies, but it might be hard with the latter, as outside of 1 card I have to create interesting rewards, without adding/removing any cards.
Well I will nerf them in the least noticeable way, by taking away their main source **Block**.

yeah
Going back to **Strike of Genius**, good card, a nice source of passive damage, great for Boss fights, and source of scaling for Strike decks.
it's kinda funny how fast these discussions can veer off topic and back on
multi lane drifting

But the wording is important here.
"This is bad" gives the impression that it should be buffed in some way.
"This is vastly outclassed" means there are different factors at play as to why an archetype isn't used.

I fully believe that Champ's strikes land squarely in the latter category. I don't think that most of Champ's strikes need to be buffed; I think the other options need to be tamed.
"tamed" is an understatement for what needs to happen to vigor unga bunga
the only thing that matters is how likely a card is to help you win

I agree, I just want to add on

the only thing that matters is how likely a card is to help you win compared to other options

If a character has 74 cards that instantly wins the run, and 1 card that has a 99% chance to win the run, the one that is a 99% chance to win is the worst card in the character's pool. Strength is relative to other options.

100 mph is absurdly fast for a car
but it is absurdly slow for light
many things are relative
So relative to unga bunga, champ's strike builds are not strong.
well champ's strike builds are also unga bunga
the only defensive strike is <flash strike>

messages.content: by "unga bunga" I meant vigor unga bunga
compared to other options does not matter. if you win, you win
Well when talking about a card's strength it is relative
i think the point is that champ is strong enough that even "suboptimal" choices still win just as much as the optimal ones

There's a lot of merit to discussing how a card can be used, its synergies, and its strengths even if it's not the best in the pool. Especially considering that Downfall is constantly being updated, it's a good idea to discuss a card's merits AND its shortcomings so the balance team can better know what people are looking for in a character and maybe better build towards that collective vision—or step in to explain what a card's intended purpose is, which could start a whole other conversation on if the card's reality is matching the intention.

Yes, any card's purpose is to get you to the end of a run and to slay the spire. But drawing on comparisons to other character kits can also be useful, especially if the card is supposed to harken to a similar role as another character (see Defect Orbs vs Slimeboss Slimes, or Ironclad Status vs Automaton Status). Cards are not made in a vacuum—and I mean this in terms of the rest of the character's kit AND in terms of the rest of base cast + Downfall cast.

> If a character has 74 cards that instantly wins the run, and 1 card that has a 99% chance to win the run, the one that is a 99% chance to win is the worst card in the character's pool.
Yes. But a 99% chance to win is still ludicrously powerful, and that is still worth talking about when discussing the card. Focusing ONLY on a card's strength relative to the other cards, I feel, constricts the conversation too much. It makes the conversation feel like, "Is this among the character's best cards? No? Then it sucks." And I think that's neither charitable or particularly *useful*, especially considering how people have been notably vehemently against using cards that they feel are "too overpowered" (like prepatch Combo). And, honestly… winning 99% of the time *is still winning 99% of the time.*

Yes, Champ's strike decks are outclassed. Again, this does not automatically mean they're bad. And talking about how they stack up to other characters' strikes could still be useful.

Alright I'm not saying we aren't allowed to discuss cards that are bad, I'm just trying to say that strength is relative to other options. I'm not saying bad cards are unplayable, just that they are weaker.
I was going to make a joke, and then realized that Reflex and Tactician are actually pretty good
I know reflex used to be really bad
"This card is outclassed" and "This card is bad" are two very different messages. That's what I'm trying to say.

There are differences, but most bad cards are outclassed. There aren't many cards that are niche but bad, and they usually are either just overly expensive or have a design that doesn't work well conceptually.
<pressure points> might be one of them?
